Wiping the dust from her face, she jogged back to the line at the base of the tower, ready for her next fall.The tower was a rehearsal; the C-130 Hercules was the premiere. It sat on the tarmac like a grey, hulking beast, its four massive propellers still, its open rear ramp a dark, yawning mouth. The day of their first live jump dawned bright and mercilessly clear, offering no clouds to hide in, no weather to grant a reprieve. The mood in the barracks was not one of excitement, but of a grim, funereal reverence. They were a company of ghosts dressing for their own haunting. Every piece of equipment was checked, then re-checked by a rigger, and then checked a final time by an officer. The process was slow, meticulous, and deeply personal. An instructor’s hands would move over Catarina’s body, testing the tension of every strap on her harness, the security of her reserve chute, the precise placement of her helmet. It was the most intimate contact she had experienced in months, yet it was completely devoid of humanity. It was the touch of an engineer inspecting a critical component, and she was the component.

The walk to the aircraft was the longest of her life. The combined weight of her main and reserve parachutes pressed down on her shoulders, forcing her into a weary, forward-leaning shuffle. The sound of their boots on the asphalt was a slow, rhythmic death march. They moved in a column of two, their faces hidden behind the impersonal glare of their helmets, their individuality erased, their shared fear a palpable, collective field of energy. Catarina focused on the back of Gomes, who walked ahead of her with a rigid, almost brittle posture, as if held together by sheer willpower. Silva, beside her, was muttering to himself, his lips moving in a silent, frantic prayer. Catarina found herself gripping the river stone in her pocket, its small, hard reality a point of focus in a world that was becoming terrifyingly abstract.

The ramp closed with a hydraulic hiss and a final, sealing thud, plunging them into a dim, artificial twilight. Then the city, the river, the bridge—her entire former world—became a sprawling map laid out below. The sight was dizzying, beautiful, and utterly alienating. She was no longer a part of that world; she was observing it from an impossible height, a place she had no right to be.

"GET READY!" The jumpmaster’s voice, amplified by the aircraft’s internal comms, cut through the engine's roar. A red light above the ramp began to glow, bathing the cabin in a hellish, crimson light. The sequence began, a series of commands that had been drilled into their muscle memory. "STAND UP!" They rose as one, a clumsy, lumbering beast of green canvas and nylon. "HOOK UP!" Catarina reached up, her gloved hand fumbling for a moment before finding the anchor line cable that ran the length of the ceiling. She slapped the clip of her static line onto it, the solid, metallic click the most reassuring sound she had ever heard. She was attached. She was part of the system. The system would work. The rear ramp of the Hercules began to lower, a slow, mechanical unfolding that revealed a blinding panorama of blue sky and distant, patchwork earth. A hurricane of wind and noise exploded into the cabin, tearing at their uniforms, a physical assault that stole the breath from their lungs.

"CHECK EQUIPMENT!" The chant went down the line, each soldier turning and checking the person behind them, a frantic, final pat-down of straps and pins, their voices swallowed by the wind. Catarina’s hands moved over Silva’s gear, her mind a blank slate of pure procedure. Silva turned and did the same for her, his eyes wide with a terror that mirrored her own. They were children playing a deadly serious game. The jumpmaster shuffled to the edge of the ramp, a figure of absolute calm in the heart of the chaos, his body braced against the gale. He held up his hand, fingers outstretched, then began to fold them in. Five. Four. Three. Two. One. The red light vanished, replaced by a brilliant, glaring green. "GO! GO! GO! GO!"

The line lurched forward. There was no time for thought, no room for hesitation. The soldier at the front vanished. Then the next. Gomes disappeared into the blue void without a sound. Then it was Silva, who crossed himself in a final, spastic gesture before he was gone. Then Catarina was at the door, the world nothing but a vertiginous drop and the roaring, all-consuming wind. The jumpmaster’s hand slapped her shoulder, a percussive, impersonal command. Her body, acting on thousands of repetitions, responded. She jumped. It was not a leap; it was a plunge into pandemonium. For two seconds, she was a tumbling, chaotic thing, her body ragdolling in the prop blast, the world a meaningless, spinning vortex of blue and green. It was a moment of complete sensory overload, a violent birth into the sky.

Then, a sudden, brutal, upward jolt that snapped her spine straight and yanked the air from her lungs. It was the opening shock, the violent embrace of her parachute as it blossomed open above her. And with that shock came the second, even more profound one: silence. The deafening, soul-shaking roar of the C-130 was gone, replaced by the gentle, almost musical whisper of the wind through her suspension lines. She was alive. She was dangling thousands of feet above the earth, suspended between the vast, empty sky and the patchwork quilt of the world below. A profound, giddy, almost hysterical sense of joy surged through her. She was a force. She was a paratrooper. She let out a laugh, a raw, whooping sound that was snatched away by the wind, a sound of pure, untainted freedom.

The world had a new geometry. The drop zone, which had seemed a vast field from the ground, was now a small green postage stamp. She could see the tiny figures of her comrades, their own parachutes like scattered dandelion seeds, drifting on the breeze. Her training took over again, but this time it was calm, cognitive. She grabbed her risers, checking her canopy for tears, her eyes scanning for the others to ensure she didn't drift into them. She looked down at her hands, the hands that had been crusted with the salt of the Tagus, and saw them confidently manipulating the lines that kept her alive. She was no longer falling; she was flying, guiding her descent. The terror was gone, replaced by a feeling of sublime, untouchable competence. This was the landscape her eyes had held all along, the one that was vast and silent, but it was no longer terrifying. It was home.

The ground rushed up to meet her with deceptive speed. The pastoral beauty of the descent gave way to the urgent, practical matter of landing. She braced herself, her body instinctively coiling for the PLF. Her feet hit the ground in a field of sun-drenched wildflowers, a ridiculous and beautiful place to land. She executed the five-point roll, the impact jarring but manageable, a familiar pain that was now a welcome sign of success. She lay there for a moment, tangled in her lines, the scent of crushed grass and wild mint filling her nostrils. She had jumped from a plane and fallen from the sky, and she had survived. She had not been broken. She pushed herself up, her body a collection of new aches and bruises, and began the laborious process of gathering the acres of silk that had saved her life. Not far away, she saw Gomes land with the crisp precision of a ballerina, and further on, Silva hit the ground like a dropped sack of cement, only to rise a moment later, raising a triumphant fist to the sky. They had all made it. They had all jumped.

That night, back in the sterile quiet of the barracks, Catarina lay on her bunk, too tired to move, too wired to sleep. Her body was a symphony of pain, but her mind was utterly still. She thought of the girl who had stared at her reflection in the dark window of the restaurant, a ghost in her own life. She thought of the fear and fury at the Sunday lunch, of her father’s weary, disappointed face. She had crossed an ocean of air to get from that girl to this one. She reached into her pocket and pulled out Elena’s stone. She held it in her palm, feeling its weight, its smooth, solid reality. For weeks, it had been her anchor, a reminder of the solid ground she had left. But tonight, it felt different. It was just a stone. The solidity, she realized, was no longer in her pocket. It was in her bones.The first jump was a breaking of the seal; the next three were the forging of a new reality. With each subsequent leap from the C-130, the initial, blinding terror receded, replaced by a cold, professional focus and a deep, humming awareness of the risks. They jumped with their rifles strapped to their sides and thirty-kilo packs harnessed to their legs, the extra weight making their exits from the aircraft more like clumsy falls than graceful leaps. The landings were brutal, bone-jarring arrivals that felt less like a reunion with the earth and more like a collision. The pastoral field of wildflowers from the first jump was a distant, dreamlike memory, replaced by the harsh, stubbled reality of designated drop zones. Catarina learned to absorb the impact, her body a coiled spring of trained muscle, but each landing left a new collection of deep, purple bruises that mapped the story of her descent. The romance of the sky was gone, replaced by the grim, repetitive physics of the job.

The announcement of their fourth jump, the mandatory night jump, cast a fresh pall of dread over the company. Jumping into the bright, clear light of day was one thing; willingly throwing oneself into a black, featureless abyss was another. The psychology of it was fundamentally different. The horizon, her anchor in the tower, would be gone. The ground, her ultimate destination, would be an invisible, rushing threat. The instructors, sensing the heightened fear, were relentlessly pragmatic. “The ground does not care if you can see it,” Sergeant Alvez stated in their final briefing, his voice a flat, emotionless line in the dark classroom. “It will be there. Your training is what you will see. Your muscle memory is your light. If you panic in the dark, you will die in the dark.” His words offered no comfort, only the cold, hard equation of survival: training over terror.

They kitted up in the dead of night, the familiar rituals of checking gear now performed in the dim, red glow of tactical lights, which cast their faces in demonic shades and made everyone look like strangers. The walk to the aircraft was a journey into a deeper blackness, their world reduced to the shuffling sound of boots on asphalt and the heavy, rhythmic breathing of the men and women around them. Inside the Hercules, the vibrating darkness was absolute, a sensory deprivation tank that amplified every internal fear. When the ramp lowered, it did not reveal a world, but a void. A cold, starless immensity rushed in, a roaring blackness that promised nothing. The green light was an explosion in the dark, a sudden, violent permission to fall into nothing. Catarina moved on pure instinct, a creature of her training. The push out the door was a surrender to utter blindness. She plunged into a cold, roaring chaos, the wind a physical presence, her body tumbling without any sense of up or down. It was the most profound and terrifying loneliness she had ever known.

The opening shock of the parachute was a violent reassurance, a familiar jolt that reoriented her in the vast, empty dark. The roar of the plane vanished, replaced by a deep, vibrating silence, the whisper of wind over nylon. She was suspended in a black velvet universe, the distant, scattered lights of a sleeping town the only indication that a world existed below her at all. The other parachutes were invisible, their presence felt only as a statistical probability, a danger to be avoided through training and luck. She performed her checks by feel, her hands moving over her risers and lines with a sureness that felt disconnected from the terror in her mind. The descent was a swift, silent fall, the ground an abstract concept until it was a sudden, violent fact. She hit with a force that drove the air from her lungs, her PLF a messy, desperate roll on unseen, uneven terrain. She lay tangled in her lines, her heart a wild drum against the earth, every nerve alight. She was down. She was whole. The smell of damp soil and cold night air filled her senses. It was the smell of survival.

Just as she began to untangle herself, a sound cut through the whisper of the wind—a raw, strangled cry of pain, followed by a frantic, tearing sound. It was close. Peering into the oppressive darkness, she could just make out a shape fifty meters away, a flailing, dark form being dragged at speed across the field. A thrill of pure, cold dread shot through her. It was a paratrooper’s nightmare: a ‘dragon’, a canopy that had caught the wind upon landing and was now a monstrous, uncontrollable sail, dragging its victim across the ground. She could hear the desperate, muffled shouts. It was Silva. Her mind went ruthlessly blank, all thought replaced by a single, clear objective. She abandoned her own chute, her training screaming at her to run, to collapse the canopy before it could drag him into a fence or a ditch. She sprinted across the dark, uneven ground, her lungs burning, her legs pumping with a strength born of a thousand runs. She reached him in a desperate, flying tackle, her arms wrapping around his legs, her added weight doing little to slow the relentless pull. The wind was a malevolent, living thing. “The toggles!” she screamed into the wind, her voice raw. “Find your fucking toggles!” Silva was being dragged on his back, his head bouncing horribly against the hard earth. He was disoriented, his hands clawing uselessly at the harness. Thinking was too slow. Catarina scrambled up his body, a frantic climb up a moving obstacle. She found the release clips for the canopy on his harness, her cold, numb fingers struggling with the mechanism. With a final, desperate wrench, she pulled them. The tension vanished with an explosive snap. The giant canopy, suddenly freed, billowed once and then collapsed into a lifeless heap of nylon, its power gone. Silva lay still, gasping, a broken marionette. Gomes arrived a second later, her face a pale oval in the dark, her medical kit already in hand.

The arrival of the instructors and medics was a whirlwind of controlled, professional action. A beam of a powerful flashlight cut through the darkness, pinning them in its glare. Silva was conscious, groaning, his arm bent at an unnatural angle. As the medics worked, Sergeant Alvez stood over Catarina, his expression unreadable in the harsh light. She braced herself for a reprimand for leaving her equipment, for breaking protocol. Instead, he knelt, his gaze clinical as it swept over the scene—the collapsed chute, Silva’s condition, her own torn and muddy uniform. "You ran," he stated, his voice quiet, almost conversational. "Why?" Catarina, her breath still coming in ragged gasps, looked him in the eye. "He was being dragged, Sergeant. Had to collapse the canopy." Alvez nodded slowly, a single, deliberate motion. "You identified the hazard. You took decisive action. You risked your own safety to assist a comrade." He stood up, his shadow looming over her. "You did not hesitate." He said nothing more, simply turned and began issuing orders to the medics. The words, devoid of praise but heavy with factual acknowledgement, were a brand on her soul. She had not hesitated.

A few days later, the letter came. It was wedged between a ration catalogue and an official circular on the barracks mail table. The envelope was cheap, flimsy, the address written in a slow, laboured script she had never seen before but knew instantly. It was her father’s. She took it back to her bunk, her hands trembling slightly as she opened it. The paper inside was a single sheet torn from a small notebook. The letter was short, the sentences simple, declarative, stripped of all emotion. He wrote that her mother was attending church more often. He wrote that Tiago had closed a big contract for his plumbing business. It was a weather report from a distant and foreign country. Catarina felt a familiar, dull ache of disappointment. It was a letter of duty, not of love. But then she reached the final lines. *“Senhor Alves from the shoe factory, his nephew was a paratrooper ten years ago. He lost a leg in Africa. He says it is a hard life but a good one. An honourable one. Your mother lit a candle for you at the Sé.”* He had signed it simply, *“Pai.”*

Catarina stared at the words, her vision blurring. *An honourable one.* Her father had sought out an external authority, another man from another factory, to validate his daughter’s choice. He had found a new box to put her in, one that was not of his own making, but one he could understand. It was not forgiveness. It was not acceptance. But it was a bridge. It was the faintest crack in the wall of his weary resignation. He was trying to see her, not as his failed daughter, but as a person living a life he had heard was honourable. She folded the letter with meticulous care and placed it in the small, empty locker that held all her worldly possessions. The final jump for her wings was in two days. The weight on her shoulders was no longer just her own ambition, or a duty to her squad. It was now the fragile, unspoken hope of a father who was learning a new language to speak to a daughter he no longer knew. She would not fail him. She would not fail herself.The day of the fifth jump, their final qualification, was marked by a profound and heavy stillness. The usual pre-jump tension, a frantic energy that manifested in nervous chatter and fidgeting, was absent. In its place was a solemn, almost priestly focus. They were no longer candidates hoping to survive; they were apprentices preparing for their masterwork. As Catarina shuffled towards the Hercules, the forty kilos of her gear felt less like a burden and more like the familiar vestments of her new calling. The roar of the engines was not a sound of impending doom but the resonant hum of a sacred space. She was not afraid. The fear had been burned out of her over weeks of relentless pressure, leaving behind a core of cold, clear purpose. She was no longer a girl from Alfama being subjected to a test; she was a paratrooper, and her job was to exit an aircraft in flight.

In the vibrating belly of the plane, the familiar sequence of commands was a calming liturgy. Stand up. Hook up. The static line clip snapped onto the anchor cable with a definitive, metallic ring. When the rear ramp lowered, she did not see a void, but her place of work. The wind and the noise were not a chaotic assault, but the conditions of her profession. At the door, she did not see a terrifying drop, but a familiar threshold. When the green light flashed and the jumpmaster slapped her shoulder, she did not fall; she exited. Her form was clean, a compact and powerful launch into the prop blast. The two seconds of chaos were now a known quantity, a brief, violent transition. Then came the opening shock, a familiar and welcome jolt, followed by the sudden, soaring silence. Under the wide, white dome of her canopy, she was a master of her small universe. Her hands moved with an ingrained sureness, pulling the risers to steer away from the others, her eyes scanning the drop zone, calculating her trajectory. She saw the world not as a distant, beautiful map, but as a tactical landscape of fields, tree lines, and obstacles. She thought of her father’s letter, of the word *honourable*. This, she thought, was what it felt like. Not a grand, heroic gesture, but the perfect, disciplined execution of a difficult and dangerous task.

The landing was the punctuation mark on a perfectly constructed sentence. She hit the ground with the practiced grace of a stuntman, her body absorbing the impact in a fluid, five-point roll that dissipated the force across her trained muscles. She came to a stop in a cloud of dust and the scent of dry grass, untangled her lines, and began to collapse her chute with an efficiency that was now second nature. Around her, the others were doing the same, a field of green figures methodically taming their silk dragons. Gomes landed nearby, her roll so precise it barely seemed to disturb the ground. Silva came down a hundred meters away with his usual lack of grace but managed to stay on his feet, letting out a wild, triumphant roar that echoed across the field. They gathered their gear and began the long march back, their column moving with a new, unspoken swagger. They had done it. They had passed through the eye of the needle.

The wings ceremony took place at dusk on the main parade ground. The setting sun bled across the sky in streaks of orange and purple, backlighting the flagpole where the Portuguese flag snapped crisply in the evening breeze. The entire company stood at perfect attention, a living monument of green and black, their faces scrubbed clean, their uniforms immaculate. Senior officers, their own chests heavy with medals and ribbons, stood before them. The air was thick with a gravity that was heavier than any parachute pack. The company was called forward, one by one, their names sharp and clear in the twilight. They were no longer referred to as recruits or candidates. They were called by their rank and name. “Soldado Almeida, Catarina.”

She marched forward, her boots striking the asphalt with flawless precision, and halted before Sergeant Alvez. It was tradition for the NCO who had forged them to be the one to bestow the wings. In his hand, he held the small, silver badge of the Portuguese paratroopers: a winged parachute with a star. His face, a landscape of scars and hard-won authority, was as unreadable as ever. He looked into her eyes, and for a fleeting second, she saw not an instructor, but a man who had seen a thousand frightened faces like hers and had decided hers was worth the effort. “The wings are not a gift, Almeida,” he said, his voice a low rumble meant only for her. “They are a debt. You pay it every day for the rest of your life.” Then, he took the badge. Instead of pinning it to her uniform, he placed the two sharp posts against her chest, directly over her heart, and with a single, firm motion, he slammed the palm of his hand against it.

A sharp, searing pain shot through her, a double-pronged sting of metal piercing fabric and skin. It was a clean, shocking agony, a final, bloody rite of passage. She did not flinch. Her gaze remained locked on his, her body rigid, her expression unchanged. In that moment of intense, deliberate pain, the last vestiges of the girl from Alfama—the ghost who cried over broken plates and shrank from confrontation—were burned away. That girl would have cried out, would have recoiled. This woman, Soldier Almeida, accepted it as the price of admission. The pain was the seal on the contract, a physical confirmation that she belonged. Alvez held his hand there for a moment, then stepped back, his duty done. She executed a perfect about-face and marched back to her place in the formation, the dull, hot throb on her chest a new and permanent heartbeat.

When the ceremony was dismissed, a strange and powerful energy swept through the newly winged paratroopers. They did not shout or cheer. Instead, they turned to each other, a slow, dawning realization on their faces. Gomes, her usual cynical mask gone, met Catarina’s eyes and gave a slow, deliberate nod of profound respect. Silva, his face streaked with tears he didn’t bother to hide, clapped Catarina on the shoulder, his touch gentle. “We did it, Cati,” he whispered, using her old name for the first time in months, a sign of a new, more personal intimacy. “We really did it.” Each of them surreptitiously touched the wings on their own chest, feeling the small pinpricks of blood that had begun to well up on their shirts, a shared stigmata that bound them together more tightly than any command.

That night, they were given leave to go to the small, cinder-block NCO club on the edge of the base. The room smelled of stale beer, disinfectant, and a freedom that was intoxicating. Catarina sat at a table with Gomes and Silva, a bottle of cold Sagres in her hand. The beer tasted like victory. The conversation was sparse, punctuated by long, comfortable silences. They did not need to speak of what they had endured. It was etched into the lines of their faces, in the way they held themselves, in the shared understanding that passed between them with a simple glance. They were survivors of the same storm. Catarina looked at her reflection in the dark glass of the window. She saw a young woman with tired eyes, a face leaner and harder than she remembered, her hair scraped back in a severe, functional bun. But the face was hers. The eyes were not empty; they were clear, calm, and held the deep, endless blue of the sky she had conquered. The dull ache on her chest was a constant, welcome reminder. She had traded the scent of salt for the smell of the sky. She had traded a cage of obligation for a discipline of her own choosing. She had wanted to be a force, and the factory had obliged. It had broken her down, melted her, and forged her into something new. She took a slow sip of her beer, the cool liquid a soothing balm. Her life as a waitress was over. Her life as a paratrooper had just begun.The silver wings pinned to her chest were a constant, physical presence. In the first few days, the twin points of pain where Sergeant Alvez had driven them home were a sharp reminder of her new reality. Now, the tenderness had faded into a dull, persistent ache, a small node of sensation that anchored her to her new identity. The wings were a key, unlocking a new level of existence within the base. The naked contempt from the permanent staff dissolved, replaced by a grudging, professional respect. They were no longer maggots or candidates; they were part of the tribe. This new status was both a relief and a burden. They had proven they could fall; now they had to prove they could fight.

The future arrived not with a bugle call or a dramatic summons, but as a sheet of paper tacked to a corkboard outside the mess hall. The posting list. A tremor of anxiety, a ghost of their old trainee fear, rippled through the newly minted paratroopers as they crowded around it. Months of being forged into a single entity had created bonds that felt as strong as steel, and the list was a hammer that could shatter them in an instant. Catarina scanned the columns of names, her breath held tight in her chest. Almeida, C. – 1st Paratrooper Infantry Battalion, 2nd Company. Her eyes jumped, searching for the others. Gomes, I. – 1st Battalion, 1st Company. A pang of disappointment. Then, Silva, J. – 1st Battalion, 2nd Company. A small, sharp thrill of relief. She would not be completely alone. She found Silva in the crowd, his broad face a mask of anxiety. "Second Company," she said quietly. A slow grin spread across his face, a sunrise of relief. “Thank God,” he muttered. “At least I’ll have someone to make sure my gear is on straight.” Gomes found them a moment later, her expression typically unreadable. "First Company," she announced. "Looks like I’m stuck with the real professionals." Her tone was laced with its usual irony, but her eyes, when they met Catarina’s, held a flicker of genuine regret. They were being separated, the three legs of their stool being pulled slightly apart, and they would all have to learn to stand on their own.

Moving to their new barracks was a symbolic graduation. They left the spartan, sterile world of the training school and entered the lived-in, scuffed reality of a line unit. The barracks of the 2nd Company were older, the concrete floors worn smooth by generations of boots, the air smelling of gun oil, floor wax, and a faint, lingering scent of masculine sweat. It was a working barracks, not a testing ground. Their new platoon sergeant, a Sergeant First Class named Costa, was nothing like Alvez. He was a short, wiry man in his late thirties with tired eyes and a moustache that seemed to hold a permanent dusting of sand from some forgotten deployment. He gathered his new soldiers without shouting, his voice a low, gravelly monotone that commanded attention through sheer weariness. "Welcome to the Second," he said, looking them over. "You have your wings. This means you know how to not die falling out of a plane. It does not mean you know how to be a soldier. Here, you will learn that. My job is to keep you alive. Your job is to do exactly as I say so that I can do mine. Find a bunk. Stow your gear. First formation is at 0600."

In this new, less frenetic environment, Catarina found the space to think, a luxury she hadn’t been afforded in months. She secured a bottom bunk and meticulously arranged her meager possessions in the locker, the act of creating order a calming ritual. For the first time, she felt the pull of the world outside the fence, a desire to connect her new self with her old life. She found a bank of payphones near the PX, the receivers battered and smelling faintly of plastic and stale breath. With a handful of coins, she dialled the number to her parents' apartment. The familiar series of clicks and rings was a sound from another lifetime. Her mother answered, her voice instantly recognizable, a blend of anxiety and hope. “Estou?”
“Olá, Mãe. It’s Catarina.”
A sharp intake of breath on the other end, followed by a torrent of worried questions. Was she well? Was she eating? Was it cold? It was the same script, the same litany of maternal concern, but Catarina felt a profound shift in her own reaction. She was no longer the resentful daughter straining against the bars of a cage. She was a soldier, reporting her status. “I’m fine, Mãe. The training is over. I earned my wings.”
“Wings?” Sofia repeated, the word alien in her mouth. “Like the man from the factory, the one your father spoke of?”
“Yes, Mãe. Like him.” She could hear her mother relaying the information in a muffled, urgent whisper to her father in the background. After a moment, his voice came on the line, hesitant and gruff.
“Catarina?”
“Olá, Pai.”
“Your mother says you have your wings.”
“Yes. Last week.”
There was a long pause, filled with the static of the line. Catarina waited, expecting disappointment, or a lecture, or just the familiar, weary silence. Instead, he asked a question that was so unexpected, so perfectly *him*, that it almost made her laugh. “Is the pay steady?” It was his only way of reaching her, of trying to fit her new, incomprehensible life into his framework of work, wages, and security. It was his version of ‘I love you.’ “Yes, Pai,” she said, a smile touching her lips for the first time in the conversation. “It’s steady.”
“Good,” he grunted. “That is good.” Another pause. “Your mother lit another candle for you.” The admission was a gift, a small, fragile peace offering. He was telling her that even if they didn’t understand, they were still thinking of her, still worrying in their own way. The conversation ended soon after, as stilted and awkward as ever, but as she hung up the phone, Catarina felt as though a great weight had been subtly repositioned inside her. The chasm between their worlds was still there, but her father had just thrown a thin, precarious rope across it.

The reality of being a paratrooper, she quickly discovered, was 99 percent mind-numbing routine and 1 percent sheer, heart-stopping terror. The days were no longer a sprint through a series of escalating challenges, but a long-distance marathon of mundane tasks. They cleaned their rifles until they gleamed, only to take them out into the field and get them filthy again. They spent hours practicing patrol formations, moving in tactical silence through the same dusty tracts of land, the drills so repetitive their bodies knew the movements better than their minds. They performed maintenance on trucks and equipment, their hands, once trained to pack the life-saving silk of a parachute, now greasy and stained with oil. This was the factory her father had spoken of. The relentless, grinding reality of keeping the great military machine operational. Many of the new soldiers chafed under the boredom, their adrenaline-fueled dreams of combat crashing against the rocks of garrison life. But Catarina found a strange solace in the rhythm of it all. Each perfectly cleaned rifle, each flawlessly executed drill, was a small deposit in the bank of competence. This was the discipline she had craved: not just the strength to jump from a plane, but the fortitude to endure the endless preparations.

She would meet Gomes and Silva in the evenings, after the final meal. Their company barracks were separated by a long stretch of asphalt, but they would find a spot on a low wall overlooking the training grounds, the setting sun casting long shadows over the familiar obstacle courses. Gomes was restless, her sharp intellect frustrated by the lack of stimulation. “I passed a law school entrance exam to do this,” she’d complain, gesturing at a squad practicing bayonet drills in the distance. “Now I spend eight hours a day learning how to properly stack sandbags. My father would be so proud.” Silva, ever the optimist, would just shrug his broad shoulders. “It’s work,” he’d say. “At home, I’d be stacking hay bales. At least here, they might let me jump out of a plane again someday.” Catarina listened, understanding both perspectives. She felt the boredom, the sense of being a small, interchangeable cog. But she also felt something else. “It’s about being ready,” she said one evening, the thought clarifying as she spoke it. “All of this… it’s the price. For the moment when it’s not a drill. All this boredom is what you buy the readiness with.” Gomes looked at her, a flicker of her old cynicism in her eyes, but she didn’t argue. They sat in silence, watching the sky darken, three small, solid figures in a world of disciplined routine, waiting for the moment they had been preparing for, a moment that was no longer a question of if, but of when.The "when" arrived on a Tuesday morning in late spring. It came not as a sudden alarm, but with the quiet, inexorable creep of a tide turning. Rumours had been circulating for weeks, whispers of a UN request, a stabilization mission in a former African colony still struggling to heal from a decades-long civil war. The whispers solidified into fact when the entire battalion was summoned to the main briefing hall. They sat on hard plastic chairs, a sea of green berets, the air thick with anticipation. The commander, a colonel with a face like a weathered map of old campaigns, stood at the podium. He spoke without emotion, his words clear and precise. The 1st Paratrooper Infantry Battalion was being deployed to Angola. A six-month tour as part of a multinational peacekeeping force. Their mission: to secure a vital transport corridor, protect aid convoys, and provide a stabilizing presence in a region where rogue militias and banditry were a constant threat. He used words like ‘de-escalation’ and ‘hearts and minds,’ but the unspoken subtext hung in the air like gunpowder smoke: this was not a drill.

The news landed differently on each of them. A wave of nervous, excited energy washed over the younger soldiers, their faces lit with the prospect of adventure, of finally putting their training to use. The veterans, the older NCOs like Sergeant Costa, listened with a weary resignation, their expressions unchanging. They had heard these speeches before. They knew the vast and treacherous gap between the neat lines on a map and the dusty, unpredictable reality on the ground. In the quiet of the barracks that evening, Catarina saw the battalion splitting along this invisible line of experience. Silva, ever the optimist, was practically vibrating with excitement. “Angola!” he kept saying, his voice full of wonder. “My grandfather worked there before the war. He said the earth is red and the fruit is the sweetest in the world.” Gomes was, as usual, more cynical, but her eyes held a new, sharp glint of focus. “Peacekeeping,” she scoffed, stripping her rifle with angry, efficient movements. “That’s what they call it when there’s no one left to declare war on. We’re going to be glorified security guards for oil company trucks.”

Catarina felt neither Silva’s wide-eyed wonder nor Gomes’s intellectual disdain. She felt a profound and unnerving quiet settle over her. She lay on her bunk, staring at the scarred metal springs above, tracing the journey that had brought her here. From a stuffy Alfama restaurant to a C-130 hurtling towards a conflict zone. The abstract desire for ‘strength’ and ‘purpose’ had led her to this. The word *Angola* was a heavy stone dropped into the placid water of her new life, the ripples spreading out to touch everything. This was the moment her father’s words became real. This was the factory’s purpose. She was no longer a component being built; she was a finished product about to be shipped.

The training schedule was immediately and ruthlessly altered. The long, monotonous runs were replaced with grueling route marches in full combat gear under the blistering Ribatejo sun. They spent days on the live-fire ranges, the familiar crack of their G3s becoming a constant rhythm. They drilled in mock villages built from plywood and shipping containers, learning the intricate, deadly ballet of urban patrol, of how to clear a room and how to spot the subtle, tell-tale signs of an improvised explosive device. They received cultural briefings from academics with Powerpoint presentations, learning a handful of phrases in Kimbundu and the complex web of local politics, a lecture that felt absurdly detached from the concurrent lesson on how to apply a tourniquet to a catastrophic bleed. Catarina absorbed it all with a terrifying lucidity. Her mind, once a landscape of vast, empty silence, was now a meticulously organized warehouse of procedures, threats, and responses.

With two weeks until departure, they were granted a final 72-hour leave. A last chance to touch the world they were about to leave behind. A last chance to say goodbye. The journey back to Lisbon on the bus was a strange, reverse echo of her first trip to the base. The city, when it rose to meet her, seemed unreal, a place from a dream. She wore her uniform, the crisp camouflage and the silver wings on her chest a declaration of who she now was. It felt both like a costume and like her only true skin. She met Elena not at a chaotic university café, but on their bench, the one overlooking the Tagus, the 25 de Abril Bridge a familiar, reassuring presence in the distance. Elena hugged her tightly, her embrace fierce and lingering. She looked at Catarina, her gaze taking in the subtle changes—the leanness of her face, the new hardness in her eyes, the way she stood as if braced for an impact. "So," Elena said softly, her voice devoid of its usual ironic bite. "You got what you wanted. You’re a force."
"I don’t know what I am yet," Catarina admitted, her voice rough. "They’re sending us to Angola."
Elena’s face tightened. "I read about it. A UN mission. It’s a mess, Cat. A political mess."
"I know."
They sat in silence, watching the ferries glide across the water. Elena, the activist who protested government actions, and Catarina, the government’s instrument. The chasm between their worlds had never been wider. "Are you scared?" Elena asked.
"I don’t know," Catarina said honestly. "I'm too busy training to be scared. The fear will come later, I think. On the plane." She looked at her friend. "Are you angry? At me? For doing this?"
Elena shook her head, a sad smile on her lips. "I’m angry at the world that makes places like that exist. I'm angry that they send people like you to fix it. But I’m not angry at you." She reached out and touched the silver wings on Catarina’s chest. "I’m terrified for you. But I’ve never been more proud of you."

The phone call to her parents was the highest wall she had yet to climb. She made it from a payphone, the familiar weight of the receiver in her hand, the smell of her mother's cabbage stew vivid in her imagination. She told her father first, keeping her voice as level and professional as the Colonel’s. “Pai, I am being deployed. To Angola. For six months.” The silence on the other end of the line was a physical weight. She could hear her mother begin to weep in the background, a high, keening sound that was pure, unfiltered grief. She could hear Tiago’s voice, sharp and angry. But she listened for her father. “Angola,” he finally repeated, the word a flat, dead thing. "Like the man from the factory."
"Yes, Pai."
"Is it… is it dangerous?" he asked, the question a monumental effort.
"It’s a peacekeeping mission. We are well-trained. We will be safe," she lied, the words tasting like ash in her mouth.
"There are no safe places in a war," he said, a simple, profound truth. There was more shuffling, her mother's sobs growing louder. "Your mother wants to know if you are coming home."
"I'm on a 72-hour leave. I have to report back tomorrow night."
"Then you will come for lunch tomorrow," he said. It was not a question. It was a command, the first he had given her in a long time that she knew she had to obey.

The Sunday lunch was a surreal performance of normalcy. Her mother had cooked a feast, an almost hysterical amount of food, as if she could protect her daughter by filling her with one last taste of home. The starched white tablecloth was out, the good silver polished. Tiago was there with Inês, his face a tight mask of disapproval. Her father sat at the head of the table, silent, carving the roast chicken with an unnerving precision. Her mother fluttered and fussed, pressing more potatoes onto Catarina’s plate, her eyes bright with unshed tears. No one spoke of Angola. They spoke of the weather, of Tiago’s business, of a neighbour’s wedding. The word hung in the center of the table, a black hole that warped the conversation around it. After the meal, when the coffee was served, Catarina knew the charade was over. Her mother finally broke, her face crumpling as the tears she had held back all day began to fall. "Don’t go," she pleaded, her voice a whisper. "Just tell them no. You can come home. Your job at the restaurant… Senhor Furtado would take you back…"
"Mãe, please."
"She's a soldier, Sofia," her father said, his voice quiet but firm, cutting off his wife’s pleas. "She cannot say no." He turned his heavy, weary gaze on Catarina. "The man from the factory. His nephew. He came back. But he was different. He said the sun there… it gets inside you. It changes the way you see." He stood up and walked to a dark wooden cabinet, a piece of furniture that had been in the family for decades. He fumbled with a key and opened a drawer. He returned with a small, tarnished silver medallion on a chain. It was a Saint Christopher, the patron saint of travellers. "This was my father's," he said, pressing it into her hand. "He wore it when he came to Lisbon from the village. To keep him safe on his journey." He closed her fingers around it, his rough, calloused hand engulfing hers for a moment. "So you will be safe on yours." It was an absolution. It was a blessing. It was the final, painful, beautiful act of letting her go. Catarina couldn't speak. She just nodded, her throat tight, the cold metal of the medallion a searing brand in her palm. The silence in the room was no longer one of disappointment, but of a deep, aching, and terrible love.The departure was an exercise in practiced, emotionless logistics. They moved in the grey pre-dawn light, a river of green flowing into the cavernous belly of a transport plane. There were no tearful farewells at the gate, no final hugs. Their goodbyes had already been said in quiet living rooms and on park benches across Portugal. This final act was for the army alone. As Catarina found her webbed seat, the aircraft already humming with latent power, she felt the cool weight of the Saint Christopher medal against her skin, tucked beneath her uniform shirt. It was a secret anchor, a tangible piece of her father’s reluctant blessing. She sat between a silent, grim-faced corporal and Silva, who, for once, was not smiling. The bravado of the past weeks had evaporated, replaced by the solemn gravity of the irreversible. As the plane taxied and then surged into the sky, she did not look out the window. Instead, she closed her eyes, picturing a steep, cobbled street and the briny ghost of the Tagus, committing the memory to a safe place before the journey ahead erased it completely.

The flight was a long, numbing purgatory, a six-hour suspension of life. When the announcement came to prepare for landing, a collective, silent tension gripped the cabin. The aircraft descended, and the sound of the engines changed pitch. Then, with a solid thud and a screech of tires, they were on Angolan soil. The ramp lowered not onto a pristine military airfield, but onto a runway cracked and scarred by heat and history. And with the lowering of the ramp came the assault. It was a wall of heat so thick and wet it felt like a physical blow, a suffocating blanket that stole the air from their lungs and made the cool, conditioned air of the plane a distant memory. With the heat came the smell: a complex, overwhelming fusion of red, laterite dust, jet fuel, rotting vegetation, woodsmoke, and something else, a sweet, cloying scent she couldn’t place. It was the smell of a continent, and it was utterly alien.

Disembarking was a slow, dazed shuffle into a new world of overwhelming sensory input. The sun was a physical weight, a white-hot hammer that beat down from a vast, bleached-blue sky. The light was different here, harsher, stripping the colour from everything except the earth itself, which was a shocking, vibrant, impossible red. The Luanda airbase was a chaotic tapestry of nations: Swedish engineers in blue berets, a contingent of formidable-looking Brazilian soldiers joking in familiar-sounding Portuguese, and local Angolan troops whose watchful, patient eyes seemed to take in everything. They were herded onto a convoy of dusty, canvas-topped trucks, the metal sides already hot enough to burn. As they rumbled out of the relative order of the airbase and into the outskirts of the city, Catarina saw the real Angola for the first time. It was a landscape of brutal contrasts. Modern buildings financed by oil money stood next to sprawling, desperate slums of corrugated iron and scavenged materials. Armoured UN vehicles shared the road with women carrying impossible loads on their heads with a dancer’s grace, their brightly-coloured capulana fabrics a defiant splash of beauty against the dust. The scars of the war were everywhere, like unhealed wounds on the land: the skeletal, burned-out husks of armoured vehicles left by the side of the road, buildings pockmarked with bullet holes, entire blocks that were nothing but rubble. It was a place where life grew with a fierce, tenacious energy in the very shadow of death.

The journey inland to their Forward Operating Base, christened ‘FOB Luso’, was a long, bone-jarring ride that shook the exhaustion deep into their muscles. The city gave way to vast, open country, a rolling landscape of tall grass, scrub, and giant, ancient baobab trees that looked like upside-down roots reaching for the sky. The red earth was a constant, a fine powder that worked its way into everything, staining their uniforms, coating their skin, and forming a gritty film on their teeth. When they finally arrived, FOB Luso was a small island of military order dropped into the immense African wilderness. A perimeter of sand-filled Hesco barriers and razor wire enclosed a small city of drab green tents and prefabricated buildings, all simmering under the oppressive sun. A Portuguese flag, already looking faded and dusty, hung limply from a flagpole in the center of the compound. This was home for the next six months. Sergeant Costa gathered their platoon, his face grim. “Welcome to Luso,” he said, his voice dry. “The nearest bar is three hundred kilometres away. The nearest threat is just outside the wire. Hydrate. Acclimatize. Your first patrol is in forty-eight hours. Don’t get complacent. This is not Portugal.”

Those forty-eight hours were a fever dream of heat and preparation. The sun dictated a new rhythm. Activity happened in the relative cool of the early morning and late afternoon. The midday heat was a stupefying force that drove everyone to the shade, a time for cleaning weapons and mending gear in a state of slow-motion lethargy. Sleep was a restless, sweat-soaked affair, the nights filled with a symphony of strange insects and the distant, unsettling sound of drums from a nearby village. Catarina felt the change happening inside her. Her body was constantly thirsty, her skin perpetually damp, her senses on high alert. The sun, as her father had warned, was getting inside her. On the morning of their first patrol, as she strapped on her body armour and checked her ammunition, the routine felt different. The weight of her gear was no longer just a measure of her strength; it was a life-saving burden. Her rifle was not an object of discipline, but her only true means of defence.

They left the wire just after dawn, stepping from the sterile, gravelled ground of the FOB onto the soft, red dirt of Angola. The world outside was immediately more vibrant, more alive. The air was cool for now, filled with the scent of dew on the tall grass and the smoke from morning cooking fires. Sergeant Costa led them, his movements economical and sure, his eyes constantly scanning. Catarina was positioned in the middle of the patrol, Silva just behind her. The silence was absolute, broken only by the soft crunch of their boots and the clipped, coded whispers over the radio. Every rustle in the grass, every birdcall, every distant shout from a village was a potential threat to be analyzed and dismissed. The tension was a low, electric hum that vibrated just beneath her skin. This was the readiness she had purchased with months of boredom. They moved along a well-worn path towards a village they were tasked with making contact with. The path was flanked by fields where women were already working, their hoes rising and falling in a timeless rhythm. They did not look up as the patrol passed, their seeming indifference more unnerving than open hostility.

As they neared the village, a group of children materialized from the tall grass as if summoned from the earth itself. They ranged in age from five to perhaps twelve, all of them barefoot, dressed in a collection of ragged shorts and faded t-shirts, their bodies thin but wiry. At first, they kept their distance, their large, dark eyes watching the soldiers with a mixture of curiosity and caution. Silva, ever the soft heart, smiled at them. One of the bolder boys, no older than ten, stepped forward. He did not smile back. “Doce?” he asked, his voice clear, holding out a small, grubby hand. Candy? Soon the others chimed in, a small chorus of requests. “Agua? Caneta?” Water? A pen? Catarina watched them, her training battling with a surge of a more basic, human emotion. These were not the smiling, grateful children from the UN briefings. They were survivors, their innocence hardened into a pragmatic understanding of transactions. Their outstretched hands were not a plea, but a demand.

Catarina’s gaze fell on one of the youngest, a little girl with hair braided into tight, intricate rows, who stood slightly apart from the others. She wasn't begging, just watching, her expression unreadable. For a heart-stopping second, the face of a little girl from her Alfama neighborhood, the daughter of the bakery owner, superimposed itself on this child. The same wide, serious eyes. The same stubborn set of her jaw. The world tilted on its axis. The girl in Lisbon would be worried about scraped knees and lost dolls. This girl, her doppelgänger, was worried about a drink of clean water. The chasm between their lives was an obscene, physical reality. Sergeant Costa’s voice crackled in her earpiece, a sharp and welcome intrusion. “Almeida, focus. We don’t engage. We keep moving.” The command pulled her back. She tore her gaze away from the child and forced herself to scan the tree line, her finger resting on the outside of her trigger guard. They moved on, leaving the children behind, a small, dusty crowd whose calls eventually faded. The encounter had lasted less than two minutes, but it had fundamentally rewired her understanding of the mission. They were not here to fix this. They were here to stand between this and something worse. That night, back in the relative safety of the FOB, the adrenaline drained away, leaving a profound and hollow exhaustion. She lay on her cot, the sweat cooling on her skin, and touched the St. Christopher medal through her shirt. She thought of the little girl’s eyes. She had come here seeking a simple, honourable purpose. But there was nothing simple about this place. The sun had gotten inside her, and it had illuminated a landscape of impossible, heartbreaking complexity. The girl who wanted to be a force was now a small, armed figure in a place where the most powerful forces were hunger, memory, and the unblinking gaze of a child.The first patrol was a baptism; the ones that followed were a catechism in the brutal theology of the place. Life settled into a grueling rhythm, dictated by the sun and the patrol schedule. The red dust of Angola became a second skin, a permanent grit in their food, their bedding, and the mechanisms of their rifles. Catarina learned the landscape not as a beautiful vista, but as a tactical problem set of cover and concealment, of fields of fire and dead ground. The villages they passed through became familiar, their initial alienness replaced by a catalog of specific dangers and predictable interactions. She learned to distinguish the sound of a woman grinding cassava from the sound of a mortar shell being seated. She learned that the sudden silence of children playing was a more potent alarm than any shout. The fear did not disappear, but it changed shape. The sharp, heart-pounding terror of the unknown became the low, chronic ache of the known: the predictable risk of a landmine on a familiar path, the volatile temper of a local commander drunk on cahipembe, the ever-present threat of a simple infection turning deadly in the oppressive heat.

The platoon adapted, each soldier forging their own armour against the strain. Silva, bless his naive heart, continued his one-man hearts-and-minds campaign. He learned a few words of Kimbundu, trading his ration-pack sweets for a child’s fleeting smile, earning him frequent, weary rebukes from Sergeant Costa. “You are not their friend, Silva,” Costa would rasp after another patrol. “You are a man with a gun. The only thing you can give them that matters is stability. Sweets don’t stop bullets.” Others went the opposite direction, their humanity calcifying into a hard shell of cynicism. They saw the locals not as people, but as a collection of potential threats, their poverty and desperation just another variable in a hostile environment. Catarina walked a line between the two. She maintained a professional distance, her interactions clipped and guarded, but her eyes missed nothing. She watched the women at the well, the old men sitting in the shade, the teenagers whose eyes held a weary anger that was far older than they were. She was a silent archivist of details, collecting expressions, gestures, and the subtle shifts in village atmosphere, storing them away without comment.

Their routine was broken by a new kind of mission: escorting an aid convoy. A Swedish NGO, tasked with delivering medical supplies and fortified grain to a series of remote clinics, had requested a military escort for the most dangerous leg of their route. The task was met with a collective groan from the veterans. NGO escorts were notoriously problematic. The aid workers, ‘do-gooders’ in military parlance, often operated with a blend of idealism and naiveté that was a tactical nightmare. They disliked the military presence, yet depended on it, creating a constant, low-grade friction. The leader of the NGO contingent was a woman named Anja, a tall, sharp-featured Swede in her late forties with pale blue eyes that seemed to see everything as a disappointment. Her khaki vest had more pockets than a soldier’s webbing, and she treated Sergeant Costa not as a military commander, but as a slightly inconvenient taxi driver. “We need to be at the Mbongi clinic before noon, Sergeant,” she’d stated in the pre-dawn briefing, her English precise and clipped. “The roads are bad, but we cannot be late. These people depend on us.” Costa just nodded, his face impassive. “My job is to get you there, ma’am. Not on time. In one piece. There is a difference.”

The convoy rolled out of the FOB gates an hour later, a strange hybrid of military steel and civilian vulnerability. Two of the platoon’s armoured vehicles acted as the lead and rear guard, sandwiching the NGO’s two battered, soft-skinned Land Cruisers. Catarina rode in the lead vehicle, her rifle pointed out over the red, dusty landscape, the radio in her ear a low crackle of professional chatter. The first part of the journey was uneventful, a hot, monotonous transit through a landscape that shimmered in the heat. Anja, riding in the first Land Cruiser, kept a constant, impatient pace, her vehicle often inching too close to the armoured car’s rear. “Tell the civilians to maintain a fifty-meter interval,” Costa’s voice crackled over the radio, the irritation barely concealed. The tension was palpable. The soldiers were on edge, scanning for threats, while the aid workers seemed to be in a hurry, their focus on the destination, not the journey.

They were an hour from the first clinic when the lead vehicle slowed to a halt. Up ahead, the road was blocked. It wasn't a formal checkpoint, just a fallen tree trunk dragged across the narrow dirt track. Lounging in the shade of a large acacia tree were five young men. They weren’t in uniform, but they all carried Kalashnikovs, the wooden stocks worn smooth with use. One of them, a boy who couldn't have been more than eighteen but had the dead, hard eyes of an old man, swaggered into the middle of the road, his rifle held casually across his chest. Sergeant Costa’s voice was calm in their headsets. “Hold positions. Weapons ready. Do not engage unless I give the word.” He dismounted from his vehicle, walking forward alone, his hands held open and away from his weapon in a universal sign of non-aggression. Catarina watched from her turret, her own rifle trained on the tree line beyond the roadblock, her heart a slow, heavy drum. This was a shakedown, a classic display of local power, a tollbooth enforced by firepower. The situation was a tinderbox. One nervous twitch, one perceived insult, and the road could turn into a killing field.

Costa began to speak to the young leader, his voice too low to be heard over the hum of the engines, but his body language was a study in calm authority. The boy postured and gestured with his rifle, his friends behind him laughing. They were enjoying this, enjoying the power they held over the heavily armed Europeans. It was then that Catarina noticed it. It was a small detail. The leader’s rifle was slung loosely, but one of his friends, a skinny boy in a faded football jersey, was holding his AK-47 in a white-knuckled grip, his finger resting inside the trigger guard. He wasn't laughing. His eyes were wide, darting nervously from the soldiers to his own leader. He was terrified. It was the same look she had seen on the faces of new recruits in the jump tower. These were not seasoned guerillas; they were children playing with men’s weapons, and the skinny one was in over his head, a liability to everyone. “Sergeant,” Catarina’s voice was a low, urgent murmur into her radio mic. “Man on the right. In the yellow shirt. His finger is on the trigger. He looks spooked.”

There was a pause. “Acknowledged, Almeida,” Costa’s voice came back, just as calm. From her vantage point, she saw a subtle shift in his stance. He angled his body slightly, turning his attention away from the posturing leader and towards the nervous boy. He didn’t raise his voice. He said something, and then, with a slow, deliberate movement, he reached into his pocket and pulled out a single, bright green apple he’d saved from breakfast. He tossed it underhand. It landed in the dust near the boy’s feet. The boy flinched, his rifle coming up slightly. The leader screamed at him in Kimbundu. But the moment of aggression had been broken by an act of utter absurdity. The boy stared at the apple as if it were a grenade, then slowly, hesitantly, he bent to pick it up. The tension dropped by a hundred degrees. The negotiation changed. Ten minutes later, after the exchange of two canisters of fresh water and a pack of military-issue cigarettes, the fallen tree was being rolled away.

As they passed through, Anja, the NGO leader, leaned out of her window. “What was all that?” she demanded of Costa. “We’ve lost half an hour. We could have just driven around them.” Costa gave her a long, flat look. “No, ma’am,” he said. “You couldn’t have.” He got back in his vehicle and the convoy moved on, leaving the boys to their cigarettes and their small, temporary victory. The rest of the journey was tense but uneventful. Back at the FOB that night, during the debrief, Sergeant Costa stood before the platoon. “Today we encountered an unauthorized checkpoint,” he said. “The situation was resolved without incident. This was due to good observation and fire discipline.” His eyes found Catarina’s in the dim light of the tent. “Almeida’s observation of the secondary threat allowed me to de-escalate the situation before the primary threat lost control of it. Good work.” The praise was stark, professional, and more valuable to Catarina than any medal. Later, lying on her cot, she felt the smooth, cool circle of her father’s St. Christopher. Honour, she was beginning to understand, wasn’t a reward you were given. It was something you built, observation by observation, decision by decision, in the vast, complicated spaces between pulling a trigger and tossing an apple.Costa’s praise, delivered with the blunt force of a field dressing, had a subtle but profound effect. It was not a commendation to be polished and displayed, but a tool to be used. In the platoon’s informal hierarchy, Catarina’s role solidified. She was no longer just the quiet girl who could run and shoot straight. She was the observer. The sergeants began to rely on her, placing her in positions where her silent, patient gaze was most effective. On patrols, Costa would often position her near him, not for protection, but for her input. A low murmur into the radio, "Almeida, what do you see?" became a regular part of their tactical ballet. Her observations were never dramatic revelations, but a steady accumulation of small, vital details: a new path worn in the grass near a suspected militia compound, the absence of a particular dog that always barked at their approach, the way a village elder’s eyes would not meet theirs. The other soldiers noticed the shift. Silva took a vicarious, brotherly pride in her new status, while Gomes watched with a look of grudging respect, recognizing a fellow professional, albeit one whose methods were the antithesis of her own intellectual approach. Catarina accepted the new responsibility without comment, the pressure of it a familiar weight, not unlike a parachute pack you learn to carry without thinking.

The rhythm of the deployment became a hypnotic, grinding beat. Patrol, eat, clean weapon, sleep. Repeat. The landscape of Angola, once so alien and overwhelming, became as familiar as the cobbled streets of Alfama, its dangers catalogued, its beauty a backdrop to the constant, low-level hum of vigilance. Catarina’s world narrowed to the 360 degrees of her responsibility. Her senses, honed by the constant need to interpret a hostile environment, became preternaturally sharp. She could smell rain on the hot dust long before the clouds gathered. She could read the subtle language of a bird taking flight in alarm. This intense, relentless focus was a powerful shield, insulating her from the larger, more existential questions of their mission. She did not have the luxury of Gomes’s political analysis or the burden of Silva’s emotional investment. Her purpose was immediate and absolute: to see what others missed, to keep her platoon alive until the end of the patrol, until the end of the tour. She was becoming terrifyingly good at her job.

The incident, when it came, was on a Tuesday, on a road they had patrolled a dozen times, near a village that was neither friendly nor hostile, just weary. The children were there, as they always were, a small, dusty cloud of them materializing from the tall grass. They had learned that this particular patrol often had a soft touch, a large, smiling soldier who sometimes broke the rules. They flocked towards the middle of the formation, their hands out, their calls of “Doce! Agua!” a familiar chorus. Sergeant Costa’s voice was a low growl in their earpieces. “Maintain discipline, Silva. Eyes on your sectors.” Silva, his face a mask of conflict, gave a slight, guilty nod. But he had a single, foil-wrapped piece of chocolate in his pocket, saved from a care package. It was a small, foolish, human gesture. In a movement he thought was subtle, he tossed it towards the children, aiming for the hard-packed dirt of the path. A scramble ensued, a flash of running limbs and excited shouts. One of the boys, the same bold one who had first demanded candy weeks ago, darted after it, his bare feet leaving the relative safety of the worn path. He took two steps into the overgrown verge. There was no grand explosion, no cinematic fireball. There was only a dull, wet, insignificant *thump*, a sound like a heavy melon being dropped onto concrete, and a single, sharp cry that was cut off before it could become a scream.

For a heartbeat, the world froze. The other children stood silent, their faces blank with incomprehension. The soldiers instinctively dropped to one knee, their rifles snapping up, a perfect, drilled response to an unexpected sound. But Catarina’s training had already taken her a step further. Her eyes were not on the potential treeline ambush. Her eyes were on the source. She saw the boy, a small, crumpled heap in the tall grass. She saw Silva, standing rigid in the middle of the road, his face slack, his rifle pointing at the ground, his entire being locked in a state of catastrophic shock. And she heard her own voice, coming from a great distance, speaking into her radio. It was a voice she didn't recognize, preternaturally calm, stripped of all inflection. “Contact, IED. Probable anti-personnel mine. Single casualty, civilian, pediatric. Location grid four-niner-seven, three-two-one. Perimeter is green. Requesting medic.” The words were a clean, sterile report, a string of data points delivered with the emotionless precision of a machine.

The frozen tableau shattered into disciplined action. Sergeant Costa began barking orders, directing two men to provide rear security, pushing the rest of the platoon into a defensive semi-circle. The platoon’s medic, a grim-faced corporal named Reis, began to move forward, his steps slow and deliberate, his eyes scanning the ground for signs of a second device. Catarina did not move. Her role was overwatch. She held her sector, her rifle sight trained on a distant thicket of acacia trees, her thumb resting on the safety catch. Her mind was a cold, clear space. She registered the scene unfolding before her—the medic reaching the boy and stopping, shaking his head slowly; the other children beginning to wail, a rising tide of grief and terror; Silva finally collapsing to his knees on the road as if his strings had been cut. She processed it all as tactical information. Casualty confirmed KIA. Local population agitated. Platoon integrity compromised by one soldier in shock. She noted the red of the boy’s football shirt, the same shade as the 25 de Abril bridge. She noted the small, silver glint of the chocolate wrapper in the dust a few feet from his body. It was all just data. The girl who had once felt a personal insult in a tourist’s happy photograph felt nothing at all at the sight of a dead child. She was a camera, recording the event with perfect, damning clarity.

Back at the FOB, a heavy, toxic silence descended on their section of the barracks. The official debrief had been short and brutal. The subsequent investigation would be a formality. The mine was old, Russian, a forgotten remnant of a war fought before most of them were born. It was nobody’s fault and everybody’s fault. Silva was a ghost. He had been sedated by the medics and now lay on his cot, staring at the canvas ceiling, his broad, kind face a ruin. He had not spoken a word since it happened. Gomes was a tightly coiled spring of fury, field-stripping her rifle with a violence that threatened to snap the metal components. “Fucking country,” she muttered to no one in particular, her voice a low, vicious hiss. “We’re just ghosts walking through a graveyard. We can’t change anything. We’re just here to count the bodies.” Her cynicism had found its ultimate, tragic validation.

Catarina sat on her own bunk, across from Silva’s still form. She methodically cleaned her G3, the familiar, repetitive motions a comfort. She watched Silva. She listened to Gomes. She waited for the emotional response she knew she was supposed to have. The horror. The grief. The anger. But there was nothing. There was only a profound, hollow stillness, a vacuum where a soul should be. She remembered the feeling of internal suffocation in the restaurant, the desperate, silent scream for air. This was its opposite. This was a vast, silent, empty space inside her, a perfectly calm landscape where nothing grew. The factory had done its work. It had taken the terrified girl and the angry daughter and the hopeful trainee and had smelted them all down, burning away the impurities of emotion, and had forged a perfect, functional soldier. The part of her that could be broken by the sight of a dead child had been successfully removed. With a chilling, final clarity, she understood. This was the real price of the strength she had craved. Not the pain, not the fear, but this. This terrifying, unbreachable calm. This was the true face of the cage she had built for herself.

She finished cleaning her rifle and placed it in its rack. She lay back on her cot and closed her eyes, but the image of the boy’s red shirt was burned onto the inside of her eyelids. She reached under her t-shirt and her fingers found the St. Christopher medal. She held it, expecting its familiar weight to be an anchor, a connection to her father, to a world where a piece of metal could hold a prayer for safety. But it was just a piece of metal, cool against her skin, offering no warmth, no comfort, no meaning. She opened her eyes and looked at her hands in the dim light of the tent. They were steady. They were competent. They knew how to hold a rifle, how to pack a parachute, how to call in a casualty report. They were the hands of a stranger. The girl who tasted of the sea was gone. The woman who had been forged in the sky was gone. In their place was a function, a role, etched in steel and silence. Soldier Almeida. That was all. And she had never felt more alone.

The salt was a constant. It lived in the damp air that drifted up the steep, cobbled streets from the Tagus, a briny ghost that seasoned every breath. It clung to the fabric of Catarina’s black apron, crusted in the lines of her hands, and she was sure that if you were to kiss her, you would taste the sea first, and the girl second. She carried the scent of grilled sardines and garlic home with her each night, a perfume she tried to scrub away with cheap, floral soap, but the ocean and the kitchen were stubborn lovers. They owned her.

Her world was a twenty-table restaurant in the heart of Alfama, a maze of clattering plates, sweating pitchers of house wine, and the linguistic chaos of tourists butchering the word *obrigada*. Catarina moved through it all with a grace born of a thousand nights of practice, a ballet of stacked dishes and feigned smiles. The muscles in her calves were tight, hard knots. Her smile, a well-rehearsed curve that rarely reached the deep brown of her eyes. In those eyes, a different landscape existed, one that was vast and empty and terrifyingly silent, a stark contrast to the cacophony of her life. She was twenty-four, and she felt ancient, worn smooth as a piece of sea glass tumbled by the relentless tide of other people's holidays.

Tonight was no different. A German couple argued over the bill, a group of American students shouted for more bread, and an old man, a regular, sat alone nursing a single glass of port, his gaze lost somewhere over her shoulder. Catarina refilled water glasses, cleared away the boneyards of fish skeletons, and answered the same question for the tenth time. “Yes, the *pastéis de nata* are very good here. Of course.” They were bought frozen from a wholesaler, but this was a truth she kept locked away with her own dwindling dreams. Her dreams, once vibrant and sprawling, had shrunk over the years, becoming small, dense things, heavy as stones in her pocket. The dream of being a photographer. The dream of travelling to Brazil. The dream of simply being someone else, somewhere else. They had all been replaced by the singular, grinding reality of earning enough to help her parents pay the rent on their cramped third-floor apartment, a home filled with the scent of boiled cabbage and unspoken disappointments.

As she wiped down a sticky table, her reflection stared back from the dark windowpane. A tired girl with her dark hair pulled back in a severe bun, her face pale under the restaurant's jaundiced light. It was a face she didn't recognize as her own. It was the face of a function, a role. The Waitress. That was all. A sudden, fierce wave of something sharp and painful rose in her chest. It wasn't just dissatisfaction; it was a kind of internal suffocation. A desperate, silent scream for air.

Later, walking home under the buttery glow of the streetlamps, the Fado music spilling from unseen windows like audible heartache, she saw it. Taped to a lamppost, stark against the ancient stone, was a recruitment poster. A woman, not much older than her, stood in crisp camouflage, a rifle held across her chest. Her expression wasn't smiling. It was something better. It was serene, confident, her gaze fixed on a distant point. Behind her, the sharp angles of a military vehicle contrasted with a backdrop of rugged, sun-drenched terrain. The words were simple, bold: *Sirva a sua Pátria. Descubra a sua Força.* Serve your country. Discover your strength.

Catarina stopped. The usual river of pedestrians flowed around her, an island of stillness in the midnight current. She stared at the woman’s face. There was no apology in her eyes, no desire to please. She was not a waitress. She was not a daughter. She was a soldier. She was a force. The poster was a door opening in the flat, featureless wall of Catarina’s future. The thought, when it came, was not a gentle suggestion. It was a detonation. A silent, world-altering explosion in the center of her being. *Eu posso fazer isso.* I can do this. The idea was terrifying. It was absurd. And it was the first thing in years that had made her feel truly, breathtakingly alive.

The Sunday lunch at her parents' apartment was a ritual as immutable as the tides. The heavy, dark wood table, the starched white cloth reserved for the occasion, the smell of her mother's roast chicken, which was always slightly too dry. Her father, Manuel, would sit at the head of the table, reading the sports pages, offering grunts of commentary on his football team’s misfortunes. Her mother, Sofia, would flutter between the kitchen and the table, a perpetual motion machine of anxiety and over-seasoned vegetables. And her older brother, Tiago, would be there with his wife, Inês, radiating the smug satisfaction of a man who owned a moderately successful plumbing supply business.

Catarina waited until the plates were cleared and the small cups of bitter coffee were served. Her heart hammered against her ribs like a trapped bird. She had practiced the words in her head, but now they felt foreign and foolish in her mouth.
“Mãe. Pai.” Her voice was thin. Everyone looked at her. It was rare for her to command the table's attention.
“I have something to tell you.”
Her mother’s face immediately pinched with worry. “Are you ill, *minha querida*? You look pale.”
“No, Mãe. I’m not ill. I’ve made a decision.” She took a deep breath, the air thick with the aromas of coffee and Tiago’s cologne. “I am going to join the army.”

Silence. A profound, suffocating silence that was heavier than the food they had just eaten. Her father slowly lowered his newspaper. His face, a roadmap of weary resignation, was unreadable. Her mother’s hand flew to her mouth, her eyes wide with a horror that was almost theatrical. It was Tiago who broke the spell, with a short, sharp bark of a laugh.
“What did you say?” he asked, leaning forward as if he’d misheard. “You? You’re going to join the army?” He looked at Inês, who offered a small, pitying smile. “Cati, you cry when you break a plate. What are you going to do when they ask you to do a push-up?”

“Tiago, stop it,” Catarina snapped, a flash of heat in her cheeks.
But the dam had broken. “Is this a joke?” her mother whispered, her voice trembling. “Catarina, this is not a funny joke. You are a girl. A good girl. You work, you help your family. The army... that is for... for rough men. For men with nothing else. You could be killed. Or worse.” The ‘worse’ was left unsaid, a dark, shadowy thing that loomed in her mother's imagination.
“It’s not just for men anymore, Mãe. The poster I saw, it was a woman…”
“A poster!” Sofia shrieked, throwing her hands up in the air. “She sees a poster and she wants to throw her life away! Manuel, say something to your daughter! Talk some sense into her!”

All eyes turned to her father. He folded his newspaper with deliberate, agonizing slowness. He looked at Catarina, his gaze heavy with the weight of his own unfulfilled life, a life spent in a factory that made shoe soles.
“Your mother is right,” he said, his voice a low rumble. “It is not a life for you. Your job at the restaurant is a good job. It’s steady.”
“Steady?” Catarina’s voice rose, cracking with a sudden surge of despair and fury. “It’s a cage, Pai! I do the same thing every day, every week, every year! I am twenty-four years old and I am already a ghost! Don’t you want more for me than that? Don’t you see I am dying here?”

“We see a daughter who has a duty,” Tiago said, his voice slick with condescension. “A duty to her family. Who will help Mãe and Pai if you’re off playing soldier in the middle of nowhere?”
“It’s not playing!” she yelled, standing up so quickly her chair scraped loudly against the floor. “It’s a career! It’s about discipline, and purpose! It’s about being part of something bigger than myself!
